details.title: Generalized Linear Mixed Models for Reliability Analysis of Multi-Copy Repairable Systems

authors.affiliation: Dept. of Ind. Eng. & Manage., Shanghai Jiao Tong Univ.

p: Furong Tan is an associate professor in the Dept. of Industrial Engineering and Management, School of Mechanical Engineering at the Shanghai Jiao Tong University, and visiting scholar in the Dept. of Electrical and Computer Engineering at the University of Tennessee in 2005. She received her M.S., and B.S. degrees in Electrical Engineering from the Shanghai Jiao Tong University. She mainly focuses on the reliability analysis of repairable systems.

authors.name: Furong Tan

authors.affiliation: Dept. of Ind. Eng. & Manage., Shanghai Jiao Tong Univ.

p: Zhibin Jiang is the professor and head of the Department of Industrial Engineering & Management, at the Shanghai Jiao Tong University. He received his Ph.D. in Manufacturing Engineering & Engineering Management from City University of Hong Kong in 1999. He has been active in research in the area of advanced manufacturing system modeling, simulation, and control. He is a senior member of IEEE, and IIE.

authors.name: Zhibin Jiang

p: Suk Joo Bae is an assistant professor in the Department of Industrial Engineering, Hanyang University, Seoul, Korea. He received his B.S., and M.S. degrees in Industrial Engineering at the Hanyang University, Seoul, in 1994, and 1996 respectively; and his Ph.D. from the School of Industrial and Systems Engineering at the Georgia Institute of Technology in 2003. He worked as a reliability engineer at the SDI, Korea from 1996 to 1999, and post-doctoral research associate in the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering at the University of Tennessee from 2004 to 2005. His research interests are centered on reliability evaluation of light displays and nano-devices via accelerated life and degradation testing, statistical robust parameter design, and process control for large-volume on-line processing data. He is a member of INFORMS, ASA, and IMS.

details.abstract: The power law process (PLP) is usually applied to failure data from a single repairable system. When a system has a number of copies for analysis, the usual approach is to assume homogeneity among all system copies, and then to pool data from these copies. In the real world, however, it may be more reasonable to assume heterogeneity among the system copies. Therefore, this paper proposes a new generalized linear mixed model (GLMM), called PLP-GLMM, to analyse failure data from multi-copy repairable systems. In the PLP-GLMM, the underlying model for each system copy is assumed to be a PLP at Stage 1, and parameters vary among copies at Stage 2. The PLP-GLMM can make inferences about both the population, and each system copy when accounting for copy-to-copy variance. A modified Anderson-Darling test is adapted to the goodness-of-fit test of the PLP-GLMM. A numerical application is given to show the effectiveness of the model

references.title: Reliability analysis for complex repairable systems

context.text: The PLP, which is proposed by Crow [1] based on the empirical formulation of Duane [2], is a NHPP model with the intensity functionwhere \$\gamma\$, and \$\theta\$ are the shape, and scale parameters, respectively.

Among the GOF tests utilized to test the hypothesis that failure-time data of a repairable system came from a PLP [1], [30]–[37], the Anderson-Darling test is shown to be one of the most powerful goodness-of-fit tests for PLP [34].

references.text: L. H. Crow, "Reliability analysis for complex repairable systems" in Reliability and Biometry, pp. 379-410, 1974, SIAM.

links.abstract: Several different and complex electromechanical and mechanical systems are shown to have remarkably similar rates of reliability improvement during system development. These similarities provide the basis for a learning curve which can be used to monitor development progress, predict growth patterns, and plan programs for reliability improvement.

references.text: J. T. Duane, "Learning curve approach to reliability monitoring", IEEE Transactions on Aerospace, vol. AS-2, pp. 563-566, 1964.

links.abstract: This paper proposes a new model, called the 2-parameter Engelhardt-Bain process (2-EBP) model, to describe the failure pattern of complex repairable systems subjected to reliability deterioration with the operating time, and showing a finite bound for the intensity function. The characteristics of the 2-EBP model are discussed, and the physical meaning of its parameters is derived. The 2-EBP model can be viewed as a dynamic power law process, whose shape parameter ranges from 2 to 1 as the syste...

context.text: When a system has a number of copies for analysis, and the system reliability may be of interest in some applications (e.g., to estimate the system reliability at the end of each stage of a TAAF program [5], or to predict a new system copy), the usual approach is to pool data from all system copies under the assumption that each copy is modeled by a HPP or NHPP (i.e., every system copy has the same intensity function \$\lambda(t)\$).

references.title: Generalized linear models

context.text: The GLIM is an important class of univariate nonlinear mixed-effects models introduced by Nelder & Wedderburn [13].
For binary, count, and categorical data, GLMM are testified to be a useful tool [13]–[18].

references.text: J. A. Nelder, R. W. M. Wedderburn, "Generalized linear models", Journal of the Royal Statistical Society, pp. 370-384, 1972.

references.title: Linear and Nonlinear Models for the Analysis of Repeated Measurements

context.text: It extends the Gaussian-based linear model to models on the exponential family of distributions, and allows the existence of a monotonic differentiable function \$g\$ that relates the mean \$\mu\$ of response variable \$y\$ to a set of regressors, \${\bf x}^{\prime}=(x_{1},\ldots,x_{q})\$, through a linear predictor \${\bf x}{\mmb \beta}^{\prime}\$, denoted as \$\eta\$, where \${\mmb \beta}\$ is a \$q\times 1\$ vector of parameters, and usually a fixed parameter vector [14]–[16].
For binary, count, and categorical data, GLMM are testified to be a useful tool [13]–[14][18].
In particular, \${\bf b}_{i}\$ can be assumed to follow any \$v\$-dimension distribution [14].

Let \${\bf X}_{i}{\mmb \beta}+{\bf Z}_{i}{\bf b}_{i}={\bf X}_{i}^{\ast}{\mmb \beta}_{i}\$, and \${\mmb \beta}_{i}={\bf A}_{i}{\mmb \beta}+{\bf B}_{i}{\bf b}_{i}\$, where \${\bf X}_{i}^{\ast}\$ is a \$n_{i}\times t\$ known design matrix for subject \$i\$, \${\mmb \beta}_{i}\$ is a \$t\times 1\$ parameter vector for subject \$i\$, \${\bf A}_{i}\$ is a \$t\times q\$ known design matrix, and \${\bf B}_{i}\$ is a \$t\times v\$ known matrix which is usually an incidence matrix containing 0 & 1 formed in such a manner as to enable one to select which of the parameters are random [14].

Expressed in vector notation, the two-stage GLMM [14] is given bywhere \$g^{-1}({\bf X}_{i}^{\ast}{\mmb \beta}_{i})\$ is the \$n_{i}\times 1\$ vector of means \${\mmb \mu}_{i}\$ expressed in terms of the inverse of the link function \$g\$; \$\phi\$ is the dispersion parameter (for Poisson distribution, \$\phi=1\$); \${\bf H}_{i}({\mmb \mu}_{i})\$ is the \$n_{i}\times n_{i}\$ diagonal variance matrix with the \$j\$th diagonal element equal to \${\rm h}(\mu_{ij})\$, where \${\rm h}(\mu_{ij})\$ is a variance function, and the variance of \$y_{ij}\$, conditional on \${\bf b}_{i}\$, is equal to \$\phi{\rm h}(\mu_{ij})\$.

references.text: E. F. Vonesh, V. M. Chinchilli, Linear and Nonlinear Models for the Analysis of Repeated Measurements, 1996, Marcel Dekker.

context.text: It extends the Gaussian-based linear model to models on the exponential family of distributions, and allows the existence of a monotonic differentiable function \$g\$ that relates the mean \$\mu\$ of response variable \$y\$ to a set of regressors, \${\bf x}^{\prime}=(x_{1},\ldots,x_{q})\$, through a linear predictor \${\bf x}{\mmb \beta}^{\prime}\$, denoted as \$\eta\$, where \${\mmb \beta}\$ is a \$q\times 1\$ vector of parameters, and usually a fixed parameter vector [14]–[16].
For binary, count, and categorical data, GLMM are testified to be a useful tool [13]–[16][18].

The random effects vector \${\bf b}_{i}\$ (not varying with \$j\$) is usually assumed to follow a \$v\$-dimension multivariate \$s\$-normal distribution with mean \${\bf 0}\$, and variance-covariance matrix \${\mmb \Sigma}\$. \${\bf b}_{i}\$ are assumed to be i.i.d. random vectors [16].

context.text: GLMM extend GLIM by the inclusion of random effects in the predictor [17].
For binary, count, and categorical data, GLMM are testified to be a useful tool [13]–[17][18].
Based on the GLIM (2), a \$v\times 1\$ vector of random effects, \${\bf b}_{i}\$, is added to the linear predictor to account for the correlation of the data within subject \$i\$ [17].
In general, the fixed parameter estimation typically involves maximum likelihood (ML) or variants of ML [20], while the random parameter estimation utilizes empirical Bayes methods [17].
For the multivariate case, the vector of the empirical Bayes estimates, \$\mathhat{\bf b}_{i}\$, is given by [17] This is the posterior mean of \${\bf b}_{i}\$.

references.title:
Goodness-of-fit tests for the power-law
process

context.text: Among the GOF tests utilized to test the hypothesis that failure-time data of a repairable system came from a PLP [1], [30]–[37], the Anderson-Darling test is shown to be one of the most powerful goodness-of-fit tests for PLP [34].

For failure-truncated data, the modified Anderson-Darling statistic [30] for copy \$i\$ iswhere \$M_{i}=n_{i}-1\$; \$\mathhat{U}_{ij}=[t_{ij}/t_{in_{i}}]^{\mathhat{\gamma}_{i}}\$, \$\mathhat{\gamma}_{i}\$ is the point estimate of \$\gamma_{i}\$.

To compare the computed value \$D^{2}\$ to critical values of the Andersen-Darling statistic (Table III in [30]) at a \$s\$-significance level \$\alpha\$, we need to specify the average failure number of the system.

According to Table III in [30], the critical value of the Anderson-Darling test at 5% \$s\$-significance level is 1.33; therefore, the hypothesis that the PLP-GLMM can be used to estimate the change trend in reliability of both the population, and all copies cannot be rejected.
The modified Anderson-Darling statistic described in [30] is applied to these data to implement the goodness-of-fit test.

links.abstract: The power-law process is often used as a model for reliability growth of complex systems or reliability of repairable systems. Often goodness-of-fit tests are required to check the hypothesis that failure data came from a power-law process model. Three statistics, Kolmogorov-Smirnov, Cramer-von Mises, and Anderson-Darling, are considered for a goodness-of-fit test of a power-law process in the case of failure-truncated data. Tables of critical values for the three statistics are presented and th...

references.text: W. J. Park, Y. G. Kim, "Goodness-of-fit tests for the power-law process", IEEE Transactions on Reliability, vol. 41, pp. 107-111, 1992.

references.title:
Goodness-of-fit tests for the power-law process based on
the ttt-plot

context.text: Among the GOF tests utilized to test the hypothesis that failure-time data of a repairable system came from a PLP [1], [30]–[31][37], the Anderson-Darling test is shown to be one of the most powerful goodness-of-fit tests for PLP [34].

links.abstract: The total-time-on-test plot (TTT-plot) and its theoretical counterpart, the scaled TTT-transform, are reviewed. It is shown how the TTT-plot can be used as a basis for goodness-of-fit tests for the power-law process when data are available from a repairable system. Both a subjective graphical procedure and an analytical test procedure based on the cumulative TTT-statistic are studied.

references.text: B. Klefsjo, U. Kumar, "Goodness-of-fit tests for the power-law process based on the ttt-plot", IEEE Transactions on Reliability, vol. 41, pp. 593-598, 1992.

links.abstract: The PLP (power-law process) or the Duane model is a simple model that can be used for both reliability growth and reliability deterioration. GOF (goodness-of-fit) tests for the PLP have attracted much attention. However, the practical use of the PLP model is its graphical analysis or the Duane plot, which is a log-log plot of the cumulative number of failures versus time. This has been commonly used for model validation and parameter estimation. When a plot is made, and the coefficient of determ...

references.text: O. Gaudoin, B. Yang, M. Xie, "A simple goodness-of-fit test for the power law process based on the Duane plot", IEEE Transactions on Reliability, vol. 52, pp. 69-74, 2003.

links.abstract: The power-law process is often used as a model for reliability growth of complex systems or for reliability of repairable systems. There are many results on estimation and hypothesis testing concerning parameters of the power-law process. Goodness-of-fit tests for the power-law process were presented in Park & Kim (1992) using Kolmogorov-Smirnov, Cramer-von Mises, and Anderson-Darling statistics. This paper considers the same problem using three statistics, Kuiper, Watson and weighted Watson. Ta...
